Historical: www.be.com{{wayback|dateTheBeBoxis a dual CPUpersonal computer, briefly sold byBe Inc.to run the company's ownoperating system,BeOS. Notable aspects of the system include its CPU configuration, I/O board with "GeekPort", and "Blinkenlights" on the front bezel.

The BeBox made its debut in October 1995 (BeBox Dual603-66). The processors were upgraded to 133 MHz in August 1996 (BeBox Dual603e-133). Production was halted in January 1997,BeBox HistoryThe BeBox Zone404April 2015wayback20120204152621http://bebox.nu/history.php?sfollowing the port of BeOS to theApple MacintoshMacintosh, in order for the company to concentrate on software. Be sold around 1000 66 MHz BeBoxes and 800 133 MHz BeBoxes.
article.heading: CPU configuration
article.paragraph: Initial prototypes are equipped with twoAT&T Hobbitprocessors and three AT&T 9308Sdigital signal processorDSPs.

Production models use twoPowerPC 600#PowerPC 603PowerPC 603Central processing unitprocessorsrunning at 66 or 133HertzMHzto power the BeBox. Prototypes having dual 200 MHz CPUs or four CPUs exist, but these were never publicly available.Interview with Joseph Palmer, Posted: 2-Dec-2005, Be Informed, The BeBox Zone404April 2015wayback20080224230323http://www.bebox.nu/news.php?lookat

article.heading: "Blinkenlights"
article.paragraph: Two yellow/green vertical LED arrays, dubbed the "blinkenlights", are built into the front bezel to illustrate theCentral processing unitCPUload. The bottommost LED on the right side indicates hard disk activity.
